content: RLS 2.0 is confusing since they're completely different codebases.
is there an RLS 2.0 code base?
Not that I'm aware of
I meant to say RA is completely different from RLS
I think the idea with the title originally was that RA would become either a prototype or the basis for what eventually becomes RLS 2.0. By now, I'm not sure that's still likely though
IMO it would make sense to rename the stream
In general I just think it makes more sense to call it by the project name
if only for newly joining people who are wondering where to ask questions about it
The name of the stream is actually just equal to the name of the working group. Sadly, organizationally we are pretty far from the t-compiler, so we don't make a heavy use of WG infrastructure.

I am of two minds here. On the one hand, de-facto rust-analyzer is a separate thing, and rls-2.0 name is confusing. On the other hand, I hate the fact that rust-analyzer is still a thing in itself :( In this sense, rls-2.0 is something we should aspire to organizationally
Is there anything we can do to bring rust-analyzer closer to RLS, organizationally?
IMO the rls-2.0 name doesn't really help aspire much, and rls-2.0 doesn't seem to imply our actual intended end state much more than rust-analyzer anyway
except by not being rust-analyzer, I guess
Yeah, that's also true.
Yeah, we probably should rename at least the stream
Although I can't do that, apparently :(
probably needs an admin

re @Laurențiu question, I believe that org structure repeats the code code structure, so we should:

  • Step 1: have more common code with rustc
  • Step 2: organize repos in such way that everything is in the single place / git hub org
Yeah, step 2 didn't turn out too well with vscode-rust.

matklad said:

Yeah, we probably should rename at least the stream

@simulacrum could you or someone else rename the stream to t-compiler/rust-analyzer?
thank you!
